posts.cooked:
Hey everyone,

Our system uses PathPlanner for autonomous paths and a Limelight for pose estimation. Currently, the autonomous routine starts from the first waypoint in PathPlanner, even though the robot could already be positioned elsewhere. Ideally, the routine should begin at the robot's actual starting pose without adjusting to the predefined first waypoint.

If the robot's starting pose doesn’t align with the first waypoint, the system automatically corrects to that waypoint before proceeding. However, we want it to simply start at its current location and navigate directly to the desired endpoint without such adjustments.

**Current Issue:**  
The system automatically adjusts to the first waypoint regardless of the robot’s actual starting position.

**Suggested Changes:**  
1. Is there a built-in PathPlanner feature that allows starting navigation based on the robot’s actual pose rather than the first waypoint?
2. Has anyone successfully implemented dynamic path starting from the robot’s current position?

Changes were made to reduce unnecessary formatting while preserving the core message.

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked: You might be looking for PathPlanners "PathFinding" which generates a path from an arbitrary starting and ending pose.

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: The 2024 version included a checkbox to ignore starting position, enabling correct pathing even when rotated from ideal alignment. However, I am not seeing that feature in 2025.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: If you are using autos, it allows you to tell it not to reset the odometer with a checkbox. If you're just using paths, you'll need to refer to the documentation to learn about the variables or methods you can use to modify how the paths function.

posts.name: Andrew J (FRC 2881)
posts.cooked: Make sure you're calling followPath, not pathfind. followPath compensates for a small amount of error from the initial pose through the PID controller, while pathfind goes to the starting point first before following the path.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked:
If you're attempting to generate an auto-alignment path, similar to creating one based on the video, I suggest avoiding pre-made paths. Instead, consider generating the path dynamically using tools like PathPlanner's create-a-path tool.  

We have successfully developed our own custom implementation for aligning to reefs.

link_counts.title: Create a Path On-the-fly | PathPlanner Docs

posts.cooked: We implemented Pathplanner’s PathfindtoPose method to align with the reef instead of generating a path on the fly. Both methods aim to achieve the same goal, but do you know if there are any advantages to either approach? Is one of them faster or more accurate than the other, or are they essentially the same?

We will uncheck the checkbox and see what changes. I think this might fix our issue with Pathplanner trying to go to the start of the path first instead of starting the path at its current location. Thanks for the tip!

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: The documentation clearly states that pathfinding should not be utilized for alignment. Our implementation of real-time path generation enables the bot to operate smoothly during motion, and it performs well in terms of both speed and accuracy.

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
Can someone explain how to implement either a Path-on-the-fly or Pathfinding at the beginning of a predefined path?

Currently, our team is developing complex autonomous systems by linking waypoints and named commands through a GUI interface. We observe irregularities (jumps) at the start of several middle paths, which may result from parallel auto-align commands executed during scoring.

We have successfully tested chained paths with uninterrupted movements between them, yielding excellent results, prompting us to seek a more efficient solution.
